reviewText:
OK.
Same engine as Borderlands 2 so you can tweak the game to make it look even better. There are New guns and combat mechanics, which are a novelty at best; lasers, double jump, butt stomping. Looks great, sounds good, if not being buggy. The Pc and npc's are very good shame the game tanks so hard. The season pass is not worth it either. Best class was for Me CL4P-TP.

That is where the good points end!

Gravity jumping Weeee. only to be shot when 3 miles in the air. killed fall back down, then attempt to get a 2nd wind.
Then we have flying loot due to anti gravity. When loot is this rare you do not want it flying off in to the Cosmos or Lava flows. Grinder was a way to deal with the weak loot system.

This instalment of the franchise, even took the shine off Borderlands 2 for several weeks. Which gave me time for quiet reflection. After many hours of reflecting, realised this was a whole lot of Tosh. 2K Purely just cashed in on the good name that was Borderlands 2. This game is pitiful in the ways you'd not expect it to be.

You'll die a lot more, mostly due to falling into space or lava or glitches in the level.

Never has one been promised so much, only to not have it delivered. Shock horror. Sell the Sizzle not the Sausage" business model was used here.

To sum up; if you have never played any Borderlands games do yourself a "Solid" Buy Borderlands 2 it is better in every way. Afterall you are Worth it!

Pre-ordering off 2K / Gearbox is now over for me."

reviewText:
is this a lot like bl2?
yes

is that a bad thing?
not really

i found bl2 to be a pretty enjoyable game, and the presequel gave me the same impression. it's fun, and a lot like bl2 to the point i don't blame a lot of people for seeing this as more of an overpriced dlc. really the only reason i ended up getting it so soon after it released (at least soon when it comes to me who gets games at least a year after they come out) was because i got it for christmas. i opened the gift like 'oh ♥♥♥♥ i forgot this was on my amazon wishlist might as well play it'.

so i did, along with a little bit of research on the way. while i was waiting for it to install, i told my friends i got it and they were like '2k didn't even wanna make this so don't think of 2k as a bad company because of it' even though i forgot 2k was even a company. another borderlands game wasn't supposed to come out until 2016, and hearing that i immediately assumed that the game was gonna feel pretty rushed. while it does, i didn't feel like it messed up the experience too much for me.

i like to call this game a very safe release. they wanted to profit off of the ip they already had without screwing it up, so they just recycled the formula from bl2 if i had to guess. if that's not it, i guess it could be used to tide people over for bl3? whatever, either way what i'm trying to say is i feel like the reason why it's basically just like bl2 is because they wanted to make it just like bl2.

there are differences, but these differences are pretty minor. these differences are all things everyone knows about: butt slams, cryo, and lazers. lazers would be more satisfying to use if they were more prone to having high fire rates, but unfortunately the vast majority of them seem to have fire rates between 1-3 with the exception of moxxi's vibrapulse. (which i'm really ♥♥♥♥♥♥ about them nerfing. it might just be me but i really don't see the point in nerfing anything that makes the game easier to play if the only competitive option you really have is duelling over loot with your friends.)

this is in vast contrast to butt slams and cryo damage which is pretty universally satisfying. (of course, cryo only goes for if you have a high chance of freezing people but that should be a given for any elemental damage.) i especially find it fun to butt slam someone and watch the rag doll physics kick in as they fly off into the void nothingness of space. it's also fun to freeze someone before slamming your ♥♥♥ on them so they break into pieces. what's hilarious is slamming into a huge group of enemies telling them to shut the ♥♥♥♥ up and they freeze to death. they're little additions that make the game a bit more fun in some parts, but still overall not much of a difference from bl2.

there are a few more things aside from the slow fire rate on lasers that make the combat system a little less satisfying though i gotta say. flying enemies are annoying. rakks were annoying in the last game, and now you have to deal with the bootleg rakks and ♥♥♥♥ing bandits with jetpacks. 'who's shooting at me i can't find them oh it's because they're floating great'. while the immediate instinct is to kill them while they're in the air, again, it's pretty annoying because whatever loot they might drop you have no choice to miss out on because it falls into the many voids of this space place. there are a lot of drops you end up missing, actually. it's usually not weapons, but more likely money or ammo that just floats away after you open any box. but this is zero-gs so i guess that's how things behave in that atmosphere? hell if i know

loot also feels a lot less...invigorating? that word sounds weird to use, let's just say exciting. loot chests feel less exciting to open. odds are what they have is ♥♥♥♥ and you can just buy something better in a vending machine. it feels pretty insulting that i'm supposed to be kind of adventuring through the moon looking for these loot chests that have these awesome legendary weapons when i'm only a level 5 and whaddya know there's an orange weapon for sale right here. (adding insult to injury you obviously can't afford these things at these levels like what the ♥♥♥♥)

okay last but not least i guess i'll talk about the plot(?). i'm not saying that fps games always have to have this extraordinary plot that'll break my heart, but what a disappointment. i'm not spoiling anything don't worry, kiddos. just saying that the ending was super abrupt. the game felt a lot shorter than bl2. i'm guessing it wasn't but it just felt like it was. it probably just does because in bl2 i was in a 3-player campaign while in pre-sequel i was by myself. i dunno. it was also pretty annoying to hear so many australian accents. i don't have a beef with australians, it just feels pretty stupid to be like 'remember us? we're 2k australia we're the ones that made this game this is our thing we did it with crayons and elmers glue aren't we cool?'.

reviewText:
Although this game is a fun play it does not live up to the Borderlands legacy. The difficulty curve is really messed up, the maps are rather poorly designed and there are not enough fast travel stations to make the gameplay fluid. That being said the humor we have come to expect is still there and most of the dialog is entertaining. Since much of the humor is clearly colored by the australian development team it might go over the head of some.

In short: Borderlands the pre-sequel is not of the same quality as either of the previous games, neither in gameplay or humor, but it fills a hole in the storyline and lets you play with some entertaining new characters.

I recomend getting it on sale as it is not worth the full price.

reviewText:
It's a really fun game, especially for me because I am in love with the characters you get to play as. Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap, Aurelia, and Jack are all such solid classes. Athena is okay, but in my opinion she's the least interesting. Anyways, gameplay is a just what you would expect from a Borderlands game: shoot the ♥♥♥♥ out of everything and get tons of loot. Also, if you love the lore of Borderlands than this is a great game for you


As a die hard Borderlands fan, this game hyped me up to extremes. I bought two copies and I honestly was a LITTLE let down. Just a little bit. I'll make a scrambled up list for my own pros and cons for anybody who shares my thoughts. I've bought all of the dlcs so I can try and review them too.

BASE GAME:

pros

- Solid story, it adds a lot to the world they've created.
- Motha. Fuggin. BUTTSLAM? Fun as hell dudes.
- The Oz kits and air system is a cool add, easy to control like it doesn't exist, but I can appreciate it anyways.
-No gravity, you spend the whole time on the moon. When I go back to playing Borderlands 2, I immediately miss flying through the air.
- The game is well-optimized. I remember it being pretty buggy here and there at launch but they resolved it quickly.
- You get to learn more about Jack, since he's your boss. Same with Nisha, Wilhelm, Claptrap (especially in his dlc) and it introduces new characters like Timothy Lawrence (Jack's body double) And Aurelia Hammerlock, the sister of Alister Hammerlock. It also reintroduces old characters from previous games, such as Nakayama. Jack's #1 fanboy.
- Funny and super amusing dialogue from the characters you play as! I'm so happy they have playable characters that can now talk, and NPCs all react differently for each character thanks to their personalities.
- If you're a gun nut.... yeah. This game.
- Jack's body double. Best. Character. EVER. (Same with Aurelia)

Cons

- The game raises more questions than answers. I'm guessing they are gonna do a lot in Borderlands 3 though, this definitely hypes for the third.
- A lot of the bosses are forgettable. They all seem to have very weak qualities that sets them apart from another. Borderlands 2 had amazing unique qualities to their bosses.
- I think this game tries a little too hard to be Borderlands 2, it tries to be wacky, and zany... but the execution left a lot to be desired.
-There aren't many character depths, usually when you meet an NPC that's all you get. Borderlands 2 had a lot of awesome npcs and characters that everyone fell in love with, you just don't get that in this game as much.
-The only memorable characters this game introduced would be Janey, Pickles, Felicity. That's about all I can remember off the top of my head.
- I compare this game a lot to Borderlands 2, which probably isn't fair, but compared to the second game, this game's quests are lackluster.
- Wilhelm's class is kinda ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t, if you're looking to play someone like Axton. His trees leave a lot to be desired. He was my main for a while and he is WEAK as hell. I quickly switched to Jack' though and don't regret it.



CLAPTASTIC VOYAGE:[/b]

pros

- It breathes SO much life into the game.
- It's fun, mesmerizing for a dlc based around CLAPTRAP.
- Brightly colored digital world, you get to see a lot of cool stuff happening and it's just hilarious.
- The whole DLC requires you to travel inside of Claptrap. It sounds 'wtf' at first but the moment you dive right in, you are guaranteed to have tons of fun.
- It's comparable to Tiny Tina's dlc for the second game. It definitely isn't at that godly on a level, but this game needed a good dcl and Claptastic is just that.
- That end cinematic though. It made me love Claptrap. This game will probably turn everybody to loving that stupid robot.
- Great dialogue, awesome soundtrack.
- YOU GET TO REVISIT ZONES FROM THE FIRST AND SECOND GAMES!
- This DLC also answers a lot of questions instead of raising them.

IT'S WORTH THE MONEY, TRUST ME.

cons

-Last boss fight is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t and I know it's gonna be hard when I do it on UTHM. pray for me


The Holodome Onslaught:[/b]

No.

Don't buy it. It's awful. The only semi-decent things to come out of this stupid dlc are the skins I guess.

Basically you just fight in a big dome, that's it. There is literally nothing to it. It's not the fun kinda fighting, either. The area is TOO big and you have to kill everybody to go to the next level. It's long, tedious, and the rewards aren't worth it. You get some audio logs from Axton and Gaige but that's all that it brings to the table. Awful DLC. Just look up all the audio logs and you'll be up to date on what's going on with them.

reviewText:
I heard from a lot of people that Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel isn't as good as the first or second Borderlands games, but honestly I'm finding that's not true at all. This game is just as good as the previous two. The class are fun, the story is engaging, and the weapons are just as great. It works nearly identically to Borderlands 2 as far as gameplay goes, with the exception of the additional oxygen feature.

I thought at first that the oxygen feature would be tedious, but it's honestly not that big of an issue. There's no micromanaging involved, and oxygen areas are easy to come by. The butt bounce it provides is tons of fun, especially with an elemental Oz kit, and the option of much-quicker resurrection of teammates using your oxygen supply is invaluable in a team setting.

There were only a few things I found wrong with the game. The soundtrack isn't nearly as good as the previous titles' soundtracks. Though I haven't yet finished the game, there doesn't seem to be as wide as range of areas to explore, especially compared to Borderlands 2 and its DLCs, but the story is interesting enough to make up for that for me. It's interesting to see the character development that Jack goes through on his descent toward Handsome Jack. The addition of Cryo-- or ice elemental-- weapons is fantastic as well, especially when pared with the DLC Aurelia Hammerlock class, which has a whole skill trees devoted to Cryo damage.

Overall, if you loved the previous Borderlands games, this one is a great addition to your collection. Don't pass it up, especially if you can snag it during a sale.

reviewText:
Borderlands: The Pre-Sequel is a sort-of sequel, sort-of pre-sequel follow-up to Borderlands 2.

It is made by a different studio, the Australian studio for the development team, and it definitely shows.

A lot of people dislike this game, and I'll be honest, I did too at first. I wasn't 100% sure about the accents, but they grew on me and I enjoyed them a lot.

The main issue I had was the movement in the overworld before getting the upgraded vehicle. It's a little tedious, and I found myself often falling off of things and having to re-do journeys, which I found slightly annoying.

However, that is a problem only for a few hours, and once gotten past, the game was very enjoyable. The story was solid, the characters hilarious and diverse and brought some incredibly interesting backstory to a lot of the characters we knew from Borderlands and Borderlands 2. Plus, the Claptrap DLC is incredibly fun and well made, as is generally all of the story-driven Borderlands DLC.

A definite recommendation from me.

Nilesy

reviewText:
When I first saw this game, I wasn't sure if it would be good. It looked like a ♥♥♥♥♥♥ copy of Borderlands 2, just with lazers and less gravity. And, luckily, I WAS WRONG.

STORY (no spoilers)
In this game you discover what happened before Borderlands 2, but after Borderlands 1. The reason I put the sentence that way is because it is way more connected to Borderlands 2. You discover how Handsome Jack turned from a low-level guy to a leader. You will see some familiar faces while you do it.

GAMEPLAY
Just like with previous games, this is a Role-Playing Shooter. So, you can choose which character you want, which skills your character will have, and which swella items will your character use.

GRAPHICS AND PERFORMANCE]
This game, just like BL2 and BL1 uses cel-shading. It's a specifc graphic style that makes everything look cartoon-ish. Not in a bad way, though. It performs really well, even on my old-♥♥♥ 2007 PC (and my gtx 960 pc)

CONCLUSION
Any Borderlands fan needs to get this game. If you haven't played Borderlands before, I recommend you play BL1 and BL2 first. If not, then just BL2.

reviewText:
I am writing this a really big Borderlands fan and because i feel a lot of these reviews forget a thing or two about TPS (What i will be referring The Pre-Sequel as)

Lets get started with the story
The story is amazing if you played Borderlands 1 and 2 the story will really make sense and you will enjoy it. Its awesome to watch Handsome Jack's character development through the story. The player you decide to play even gets unique dialogue to say in this game at certain parts some characters are smart asses some are funny its a welcome addition as now your character isn't completely like a killing machine. In short the story is pretty fantastic if you played Borderlands 2 if not go play Borderlands 2 you'll see why in a minute.

The characters and skill trees
As i said above the character's dialogue is perfect and a welcome addition but the choice of characters is pretty cool as well. You will get to select out of 4 familiar vault hunters or 6 with the DLC as much i would love to sit here tell you the most OP builds for them all i'm just going to say this: They are all good it is not like Borderlands 2 where there is a character or 2 are terrible at the end game *Cough* Axton *Cough* they are all good and can pretty much succeed at anypart of the game some are still better than others but its not like Borderlands 2 in the fact there are harder characters to play than others. The skill trees which is the most important of the characters are the best yet in Borderlands. It makes you wish they would maybe do some kind merge with TPS and Borderlands 2 and let you play as TPS characters and vice versa. Anyway back on topic the skills actually synergize well with other skills even if different trees and characters. Picking a character and leveling him up and working on builds is really fun in TPS.

Loot and rarites
This is where my review starts to get a negative and you might be thinking how could this be bad after that well i said at the start that i am writing this a really big Borderlands fan as i am, i have played every Borderlands for countless hours on console and PC. Which leads to the huge problem of TPS: Legendaries are mostly returning or reskins with slight different mechanies. Although some of you might be happy that there is no Norfleet therefore shamfleeting or Unkempt harold. This is still a problem but this issue has been somewhat resolved with the new DLC claptastic voyage which adds new legendaries and a new rarity called glitch weapons but if you're not buying the DLC then don't bother about this sentence.

Endgame Scaling and Farming
Lets start with another positive scaling is heaps better in TPS and doesn't go into terriblely unfun levels like Borderlands 2. Scaling is better in TPS enough said but farming took a hit when the game released with no respawnable bosses. Although this has been resolved with a patch it was a problem and took a bit too long to fix which is why most Borderlands fans are playing Borderlands 2.

DLC
The DLC packs for TPS are pretty good besides Holodome which is terrible and should only be bought if you are level 60 and want to be level 70. The other packs like the Doppelganger pack and Baroness pack are good but not %100 necessary at all. The only DLC you really need if you are playing casually or want more endgame is Claptastic Voyage which is one of the best DLC's i have ever played its packed with new content and a raid boss although people say not technically i think the last boss was an intended raid boss as it is pretty difficult. Glitch weapons are pretty cool as they get random buffs when you reload after emptying a clip some as simple as faster fire rate to your weapon shooting shotgun bullets thats right you ever wanted an assault rifle that could randomly start shooting shotgun shells? Well thats now possible with glitch weapons.

In Conclusion
TPS is a welcome game in the Borderlands franchise but i must say if you're new to Borderlands and reading this to see if you should buy this to start with Borderlands, buy the Borderlands 2 GOTY edition on sale its worth it as its cheap, fun and much better than TPS. But if you're like me, played all the Borderlands games, done your fair share of shouting at that bandit moving behind cover when you need a second wind then i might say buy this with Claptastic voyage if there isn't anything else to spend your money on and you need something to play or do. TPS might satisfy you

reviewText:
If there was a mixed choice, I would choose it.

This game is particualar bad, but it also isn't the greatest game ever.

Like most people would say, this game should have been made a DLC. It seems too short and a waste of money. I only paid $24 + a free Shock Drop Slaughter Pit (cuz I bought the retail ver). This game isn't worth the full price. If you really want this game, buy it during the Steam sales or the retail ver.

The story of this game is how Jack rose to power and you help him get to the vault and essentially save Pandora and Elpis. Everything in this game is pretty much like BL2 besides the added cryo element, laser guns & slam damage. The character classes aren't all that great. DLC characters Doppelganger Jack and Lady Hammerlock seem to be better choices. And don't count on new legendaries in this game. They're a direct copy of BL2 legendaries and only a few new ones are added. If you buy the Claptastic Voyage DLC, you get access to Glitch weapons. Which are kinda cool but not really special. The humour in this game is dry, the missions mostly require you to run back in fourth to point A to point B.  Oh and in order to get Vault Hunter Pack up to level 60 (max), you need to buy both Pack seperately. The Holodom is worthless, I didn't buy it but you could just watch the playthroughs on YouTube and the only reason that it worth buying is the dialouge between Axton, Athena and Gaige. Shock Drop is completely worthless, its just another set of slaughter rounds. The game gets boring very quickly becuase of the lack of missions.

Its an okay game for people who've played BL2, but if you're just starting out, you're not gonna understand anything the character will be talking about.

/long review, sorry! >_<

reviewText:
Disclaimer: normal mode is 100% done and TVHM is around 95% done, I've tried all the characters (except Wilhelm). Claptrap lvl 50, Athena lvl 32 (in progress), Nisha lvl 29.

Story
Jack discovers a vault on Elpis (Pandora's moon) and wants to open it, so he recruits 4 vault-hunters (Nisha, Athena, Wilhelm and Claptrap), but right when they're getting to the moon, Helios gets brutally attacked (and subsequently overtaken) by Dahl's armed forces, commanded by Tungsteena Zarpedon. Apparently, Zarpedon doesn't want Jack to find out what's inside the vault, so she does everything in her hand to stop both Jack and YOU from opening it.

The story as a whole is very promising, but the delivery is as bland as it gets; however, you get to see how an apparently harmless engineer like Jack turns into a full-blown villain (Handsome Jack), and when you finish the game you'll either side with him and develop a burning hatred for Lilith and Moxxi (like I did) or hate him even more.


Gameplay
First things first: the intro is awesome. Now let's talk about the gameplay.

Change relics for oxygen packs, slag for ice and eridium for moonstones and you've got the system figured out.

This first-person-shooter with RPG elements feels very stretched. Most main missions follow the same pattern. I'll use the letters of the alphabet so you get an idea of how far places are apart from each other:
Get to A (kill wildlife, A is closed)
Get to F (kill a sh*t-ton of enemies that attack you for no reason)
Get thing back to A (kill another sh*t-ton of enemies)
Thing doesn't work, go to M (enemies and wildlife, M is blocked)
Find a way to open the gate/cross the bridge/break the barrier (enemies intensify)
Get thing back to A (thing works)
Get working thing to E
Mission completed
And that's basically the game. It feels incredibly and unnecessarily stretched, to the point that sometimes it gets so overwhelmingly boring you have to get back to Borderlands 2 and play with Gaige♥ again.

But apart from that, let me list the BAD before getting to the GOOD.
NPCs talk too much and sometimes they talk over each other, interrupting vital dialogue to talk about their ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ tales and stories and even hitting on you (I'm looking at you, Springs)
The loot is mediocre; most AR and SMGs are garbage, and since Boganella and Moxxi's vibra-pulse are fairly overpowered and easy-to-get, they'll get you through the main story without sweating a drop. Legendaries and very-rares are pretty much non-existant (even in TVHM) and once you get a good oxygen kit you'll never feel the need to change it again
The bosses are easy (except RK5, f*ck that), and the last boss is a disappointment in normal mode, and even the invincible version is doable in the first try
Enemies are boring and they have a huge lack of personality. Even though they talk a lot and mimic psycho moves (running at you and throwing stuff at you), they all look the same and feel like clones that attack you for no reason. Who are they? Why are they still on the moon if they can afford space suits, lasers, rockets and turrets? Kraggons and torks don't seem tasty at all and there's no water to be seen
The whole zero-G novelty wears off fast, and sometimes you'll miss the ability to run normally
Buying ammo is tedious (especially for lasers), there's still no restock full ammo" option
Now let's get to the good stuff

reviewText:
Borderlands: 2 with Low Gravity, Glitches, Recycled Material and Boredom.

Re-writing now that I've played more.

First off, I'm a big Borderlands fan. It took me a half hour to get used to the look in the first game, and I've loved it ever since.

Pre-Sequel is a ripoff as a full-price game; it should have been an expansion. Not only because of how short it is, but because of the absolute laziness put into its design. The lack of polish is immediately obvious, and laziness quickly becomes evident when you realize a lot of objects are just retextured bits from B2. I've even heard recycled sounds, as well, not to mention reused dialogue for the vending machines and such.

The next thing that quickly becomes obvious is that the OZ mechanic is a complete gimmick; generally all it serves to do is pull you away from whatever tedious quest you're working on so you can rush off an find a few canisters, then trek back and complete whatever you were doing. Sometimes it's cool to shoot an oxygen helmet off of a bad guy and watch it damage his health, but generally it's much faster to just shoot them again instead of waiting for them to die.

Low gravity had excellent potential, but the implementation is lacking. There's very little that makes actual use of it; most of the time it just ends up being a way of skipping over parts of a map, except when there's a half-a$$ed platforming section thrown in for no reason. But the biggest problem with the low gravity is that when you kill an enemy carrying a mission-critical object, YOU HAVE NO IDEA WHERE IT WILL GO. I had to restart just a few minutes into a mission because the stuff an enemy was carrying shot into the side of a mountain out of reach. That is dumb.

Balance is definitely not as good as B2. Sometimes you'll find yourself painfully outgunned, to the point of frustration (especially in early stages). I don't know how much of my money was wasted on respawns that should not have happened; many of the enemies are far, FAR more powerful than they should be. On the other hand, sometimes you'll find a rifle that can kill a scav in one or two non-critical hits.

Pickles makes me want to stab my ears out. And it's particularly jarring to hear a Cockney Brit amongst all the Australians... seriously, why is everyone on Elpis Australian? There are PLENTY of non-Aussie voice actors in Australia! DON'T BE LAZY!!!

I'm not homophobic. I believe in freedom. I think homosexuals should be free to marry who they want. But are there ANY non-gay couples in this game??? Seems like every other person has a same-sex partner. Maybe it's something in the OZ...

Level design is alright but not very imaginative, and most areas feel tight and constricted, which makes the overpowered enemies even tougher. More problematic is that some of the levels are PAINFULLY long and not very well designed for future side missions, I.E. you'll have to run for an hour killing low-level enemies to make to an objective. It's frustrating and boring.

Hitbox glitches are probably the most annoying problem of the game so far. I've run into many instances where I'll fire a full mag at someone without hitting them, at point blank range... then move a couple of feet to the side and start hitting them. It sucks.

Driving is awful, but that's to be expected (one of the weak points of all the games). The worst part is that a lot of jumps are not actually possible unless you hit absolutely PERFECTLY, which is frustrating when you're just trying to relax and enjoy yourself.

WHY DO I NOT AUTOMATICALLY PICK UP ALL AMMO AND MONEY AND WHY DO I HAVE TO MANUALLY PICK UP MOONSTONES?? Also, be careful opening chests... you might do what I did, not pay attention and spend 40 moonstone to open a chest full of WORTHLESS loot" when I could have spent it on storage upgrades.

Moxxi... poor Moxxi. She's been reduced to a sex object

These are not all my complaints. But I'm bored of writing about it; that's how dull this game is.

reviewText:
Note: Since this game is a sequel, and in many aspects very similar, to Borderlands 2, I will assume familiarity with this and only talk about differences.

Many of the reviews, as well as most forum threads, complain about The Pre-Sequel (TPS from now on) being merely a huge DLC to BL2. While this is technically correct - the engine is the same, and the gameplay is not changed so much that it could not have been done in an expansion pack back in the day - I will explain why I still think TPS is an improvement over the (already amazing) BL2 and definitely worth getting.

GameplayThe gameplay formula of BL2 remains the same - shoot, slaughter enemies in amazingly creative ways, loot. However, there is one notable new feature: Oz kits and low gravity allow you to jump huge distance, slam down on enemies and even float in the air for short durations - and of course, enemies can do the same. While this may not sound like much on paper, it is a huuge improvement for the game. It really mixes up the gameplay, and to me it feels as if this is really what Borderlands needed all along.
Laser Guns dont have all that much of an impact, but it's still a nice addition. Slag is gone and replaced by the (even more powerful) cryo, that still amplifies damage but also freezes enemies.
In short: If you enjoyed BL2's gameplay, you'll enjoy TPS as well only more so because buttslam.

BalanceEveryone who played BL2 will remember its shortcomings: Exponential scaling that, at higher levels, made every weapon with even 1 level too less and every direct-damage skill useless. Thankfully, this is changed in TPS; although scaling is still exponential, and direct-damage skills still fall off somewhat towards high-level, the effect is much less noticeable and builds based on damage skills are totally viable even in the endgame. As a consequence, the game is much more enjoyable, although the masochists among you might find it too easy at times.

Class balance is also vastly improved - all classes can be OP in some way, all classes have unique, interesting skills and multiple ways to play. I consider even the (imo) least interesting class in TPS more interesting than my favorite in BL2.

StoryThe story is, as is expected from a Borderlands game, obviously no high literature. But it is well-written and interesting (imo more so than the story in BL2), and the new information gained about Handsome jack's rise to power brings interesting new points of view to the established lore.

As usual, there are lots of jokes, which you might find funny or not, but does this surprise you? It's Borderlands.

Some people complain about social agenda" forced into the game. I do not feel that this is a valid complaint

reviewText:
The first week of playing this game I had 90 hours played total so I enjoyed it for what it was but it's not a properly worthy sequel to Borderlands 2. I know that Gearbox wanted to make this as a filler game to fill in gaps and questions fans had about the events that lead up to Handsome Jack's takeover of Hyperion, especially for people who've played both Borderlands 1 and 2, and it shows. This is just here to hold you over until Borderlands 3 comes out.

Some people complain that this is just Borderlands 2 in space and they're essentially right. However, I don't see that as a negative thing since I loved Borderlands 2 (I have approx. 400 hours into that game). I expected it to be nothing else actually. It's a Borderlands game. It should look like a Borderlands game and it should play like a Borderlands game, and it pulls that off perfectly. When you go back to BL2 after playing this game you actually realize how much you miss the butt slams and the Oz kit boost ability.

Now, the main problem I had with this game is that it felt way too short in comparison to BL2, especially for a game priced as a triple-A full length title. The main quest line felt too lackluster. Again, it's good for what it is but it wasn't worth €50. If it had been priced at €35-40 I could see it being a more resonable price for this game.

Another thing I didn't like about this game was that there was WAY too much dialogue where it didn't need any. I'm gonna quote TotalBicuit here and say that it's the game that likes to hear itself talk". It can become a bit annoying here and there and the plot points they're trying to get across to the player could either be left out completely or just be explained in a much simpler manner that didn't need 2 minutes of NPC dialogue.

All in all it's a good game with minor flaws and I recommend you buy this when it's on sale."

reviewText:
I can't believe I'm recommending this game.  But I am.

After enduring the lackluster, ♥♥♥♥♥♥ writing of Borderlands 2, I was skeptical about the pre-sequel.  I was ESPECIALLY skeptical about the sixty-dollar price tag.  But I'm glad it all turned out well (sort of), in the end.

As it happens, the pre-sequel is a more balanced gameplay experience, and much more challenging - but in a good way - than its predecessors.  Gone are the obliterating alpha strikes of badass enemies in BL2.  There are far fewer WTF gear gates and gimmicky asshats who one-shot you regardless of spec.  Now the ride is smooth, for the most part - the difficulty really spikes once you get into True Vault Hunter Mode, and the game will massacre you if you're ill-prepared.  But on the whole, things are way more fun, and ten times more mobile.

The writing blows Borderlands 2 out of the water.  I hated the writing in Borderlands 2 for reasons irrelevant to this review.  The Pre-Sequel actually reduces the amount of inane nattering in your ears from characters trying far too hard to be clever (or worse, clumsily TELLING you to care about some problem or issue or person or whatever when no one has SHOWN you why you should).

In BLTPS, instead, it presents you with surprisingly dark storytelling, a nuanced world, and incredible pacing.  This game is intense, and highly economical.  Not a moment is wasted.  It's still got some very funny moments, and I find the Scavs to be far more entertaining than the Bandits of BL2.  Some of these Australians sound so authentic, it's like they're gargling a wallaby for some of these lines.  Just deep, throaty stuff.  Delightful.

One of the darkest corners of the plot regards the rarely-trod avenue of artifical intelligences and the ethical treatment thereof.  I won't spoil anything, but it's chilling.

The cast of characters is amazing.  Claptrap is hilarious, yet surprisingly poignant and tragic, in his own sideways fashion.  Wilhelm is a refreshing breath of stoic masculinity in a medium plagued by try-hards and wanna-be ubermenschen alpha-nerd projections.  Nisha is at first hateable and seemingly two-dimensional, but unlocking more of her backstory reveals not just a cute 'for funsies' sadist, but an actual born-again psychopath who suffered the kinds of traumas that make modern serial killers.

And then there is my absolute favorite, Athena.  In a world starved for powerful, matronly female role models, Athena takes the cake - she is both sexy and professional, modest, yet bold.  She doesn't mince words, and she makes her presence known through minimal effort.

In addition to the characters being stronger, there's also a great deal more individuality on the part of the PCs - your character responds to dialogue, to other characters, and there are plenty of in-combat call-outs geared toward specific partnerships (when one player activates their special ability, the other characters call out and notice).  Little touches like these are what seperate good games from great games.

On top of all that, the environments are gorgeous and colorful, and the music is a FANTASTIC retro-future ensemble - think EVE Online meets Bladerunner meets When Mars Attacks!

I could go on and on.  The game is amazing.  Why it has a low metacritic score, I can't imagine.  I hated it at first for the difficulty, but once I acclimated, and changed some of my bad habits from Borderlands 2, I loved it.

Give it a try.  The price tag is steep, I know.  Maybe wait until it goes on sale.  But if you can afford it?  Go for it - especially if you have friends to play with.

OLD REVIEW
Borderlands The Pre-Sequel... The latest installment of everyone's favourite loot and shoot series.

However, it gets a lot of hate for being practically DLC for Borderlands 2. The hate it gets is not deserved, this is still an amazing game, aside from the fact that is the same stuff.

Pros & Cons
+ Butt Slamming and Oxygen is the best mechanic ever!!!
+ Amazing Story
+ Funny Writing
+ NPCs now recognize you as a certain character, giving you different dialogue...
+ Your characters do way more talking (probably a bad thing for Claptrap as he is annoying as)
+ The new playerable charcters have interesting skills, branching away from the Commando, Assassin, Siren and Gunzerker sets.
+ THE NEXT BORDERLANDS IS COMFIRMED!!!!
+ References to thousands of other movies and games!
+Nappykins Lunestalker, nuff' said.

- Start is really slow
- Oxygen drops are probably the most common drop... Please make Oz a little bit harder to get...
- About 5 missions take place on Helios (Not included Watch Your Step as it has Zero-G) out of 12 missions in the game... On Helios, there is no zero-g D:... Making buttslams near to impossible to do...
- I didn't like most of the Austrailians (Not being racist or anything), I just felt that their writing was poor and they weren't funny at all (I think Gladstone was the only funny one, just by a wee' bit)


Borderlands The Pre-Sequel is a must get game, however I'd reccomend playing through Borderlands 2 first as it certainly helps you understand what is going on. If you loved Borderlands 2, then you will certainly love this new entry into the series

reviewText:
There have been some damning reviews of this game, but I can honestly say that I, personally, love it.

Don't get me wrong - it's NOT as good as Borderlands 2. But then, very little is as good as Borderlands 2. And to say that this compares is really good enough.

I like that they haven't changed the look and feel very much. The second game worked well, and, as they say, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

But at the same time, it is suitably different to be a different game. They've made the vending machines actually worth looking at, and the new types of gun are fun. Being on the moon is great; I spend half my time literally flying around, and, yes, butt slamming the bad guys at every available opportunity. There are different mechanics, such as grinding, which, once you've got it worked out, can be really good (for example, I put in purple weapons and got an orange out, I thought that that was pretty worth it). There are also more things to do with moonstones (the equivalent of eridium from borderlands 2) - you can, of course, use them on the black market; but you can also use them to get better grinds, to buy boost drinks from Moxxi (I haven't tried those yet) and to, occasionally, open chests of rare goodies out on a mission (not recommended from my experiences). Also, they seem to be more common than eridium, you tend to get them from killing Badasses.

As for the length of the game... well, at the time of this review (26 hours of playtime) I hope that I have plenty of time left (yes, I do ALL the side missions, I like to complete the game, if you don't like side missions, why are you playing this game?). However, I understand that it IS a shorter game, already it feels like the story is advancing more quickly than in borderlands 2, with less side missions to do between story missions - so if there is one I would suggest about buying it, it's probably DON'T buy it at full price. I got mine on sale for about £20, which is good for such a new game, and I don't regret it (especially as I only paid £5 for Borderlands 2 and I've got so much fun out of that too, I didn't mind giving some more money that I'd normally spend on a game on steam).

The only problem with the game itself is that it's a bit glitchy sometimes (especially in multiplayer). But you get used to it, and often the glitches are funny (like a friend of mine, who shall remain nameless, having claimed his shift code golden keys, came on the next day and found them back in the key dispenser, and now has double keys, which is hilarious and we have unlimited purple weapons for a while). It was just quite noticeable after Borderlands 2, which I found pretty flawless in terms of gameplay.

Anyway, I like this game a lot. I certainly wouldn't call it disappointing, although there ARE some flaws, which doubtless other reviewers will describe to you in excessive length. But I'm having fun, with just enough familiar, and plenty of new, and actually quite a lot of back story to Borderlands 2, which is nice.

9/10 if you get it on sale

reviewText:
Played about a good 50+ hours so far, finished the main game and the Claptastic Voyage, currently busy with TVHM.

Honestly, i really don't get much of the negativity surrounding TPS, it's a fantastic game. The game has a number of flaws (in comparison to B2) but also has a lot of features that redeem it. I'll just list up the pros and cons.

Pros:

- Excellent storyline. Whereas i couldn't be arsed about B2's storyline, TPS does so a lot better. Everybody has a knack for Jack (pun intended) and TPS is focused around his side of the story that lead up to the events of B2. Don't wanna spoil it so i'll keep it short. The story will give you a lot more perspective on Jack, and why he's such a psycho hell-bent on reducing Pandora to rubble, and what morality he bears to it. You'll get to see his reasons for it.

- Plenty of new additions. For example, slag has been removed and replaced with cryo damage. It's essentialy still the same thing, as it boosts damage, but enemies will be slowed or paralyzed for a few seconds, making it a far more effective elemental weapon. A new weapon is also introduced: Lasers, which is pretty much as awesome as it sounds.

- Money is essentialy worthless in B2, with the exception of grinding slot machines. (which rarely give anything good anyway, so its mostly exchanging it for Eridium) Not the case anymore, vendors reguraly have excellent items on stock, even the occassional legendary item. And they dont come cheap. Money is an essential part, and paying a respawn fee is now something you want to avoid. Along with that, there's the 'Grinder', a machine that can turn items and weapons you don't need into something new, with a good chance of them increasing in rarity level. (for example, 3 green items can be turned into a blue one)

- Level scaling is a lot better, with the 'Triton Flats' (an area which you will reguraly be returning to) set to your current lvl as the story progresses. Backtracking, grinding and looting is thus also a lot more viable if you wish to do so.

- I've encountered a lot of bugs in B2, including a pretty gamebreaking one. It's annoying. TPS has a lot less 'rough edges', in the 50+ hours i've spent i have passed by barely any bugs at all.

- A whole new cast of characters with entirely different playstyles. Whereas B2 regurgitated some of the characters from B1 into B2 (Commando being Roland, Gunzerker being Brick, etc.) every character in the game has its very own special skillsets and are extremely enjoyable as well.

-There's lots of new enemies everywhere, which is awesome. Unfortunately though, some of them are mostly 'repackaged' enemies from B2. (Kragoons being Skags, Scavs being bandits, etc.)

Cons:

- It's shorter than B2. Fewer sidequests and a slightly shorter (though more enjoyable) storyline.

- Little new weaponry. There's the lasers they added, which are awesome, but they've mostly ported the arsenal from B2 to TPS. I would've enjoyed seeing some new weapons around. Though, thankfully, there are a good number of new legendaries (quite a lot, actually) to find, and i've encountered a few high-lvl weapons (blues/purples, though i could be wrong and these have been ported from B2 as well) that i haven't seen before. It's still a shame though. For a game that focuses so much on loot and progression, some new flavors would've definetly been appreciated. Claptastic Voyage includes a new rarity level (Glitch) and new weapons which are awesome, but you won't find them in the vanilla game so i don't really think they count.

- They've really tried to bring back that feel of humor from it's predecessors and implemented it into TPS. Yeah, i've laughed heartily a few times, but they've tried to give you the occasional chuckle every now and then. Or at least, that's the aim. Thankfully, none of it feels forced, but it's just not funny most of the time.

- The whole low gravity thing is awesome, but the fact that you have to maintain your oxygen is just annoying. Occasionaly you'll have to run off to a location containing oxygen when you're on your way. Instead of keeping the pace, you're just gonna have to stop every now and then. For absolutely no reason whatsoever. It's not a feature Gearbox, it's just annoying.

- It may not be something for everyone, but the DLC is - aside from the Claptastic Voyage (which is amazing by the way) - pretty little. B2 has huge amounts of excellent DLC (DLC done right), TPS has far less. Of course, this shouldn't affect the rating of the game, it's an add-on after all.

In conclusion, i recommend B:TPS. Though i urge every person new to the series to start out with B2 (you dont need B1 if you dont wanna), if you want some more of it, totally get TPS. reviewText:
There have been some damning reviews of this game, but I can honestly say that I, personally, love it.

Don't get me wrong - it's NOT as good as Borderlands 2. But then, very little is as good as Borderlands 2. And to say that this compares is really good enough.

I like that they haven't changed the look and feel very much. The second game worked well, and, as they say, if it ain't broke, don't fix it.

But at the same time, it is suitably different to be a different game. They've made the vending machines actually worth looking at, and the new types of gun are fun. Being on the moon is great; I spend half my time literally flying around, and, yes, butt slamming the bad guys at every available opportunity. There are different mechanics, such as grinding, which, once you've got it worked out, can be really good (for example, I put in purple weapons and got an orange out, I thought that that was pretty worth it). There are also more things to do with moonstones (the equivalent of eridium from borderlands 2) - you can, of course, use them on the black market; but you can also use them to get better grinds, to buy boost drinks from Moxxi (I haven't tried those yet) and to, occasionally, open chests of rare goodies out on a mission (not recommended from my experiences). Also, they seem to be more common than eridium, you tend to get them from killing Badasses.

As for the length of the game... well, at the time of this review (26 hours of playtime) I hope that I have plenty of time left (yes, I do ALL the side missions, I like to complete the game, if you don't like side missions, why are you playing this game?). However, I understand that it IS a shorter game, already it feels like the story is advancing more quickly than in borderlands 2, with less side missions to do between story missions - so if there is one I would suggest about buying it, it's probably DON'T buy it at full price. I got mine on sale for about £20, which is good for such a new game, and I don't regret it (especially as I only paid £5 for Borderlands 2 and I've got so much fun out of that too, I didn't mind giving some more money that I'd normally spend on a game on steam).

The only problem with the game itself is that it's a bit glitchy sometimes (especially in multiplayer). But you get used to it, and often the glitches are funny (like a friend of mine, who shall remain nameless, having claimed his shift code golden keys, came on the next day and found them back in the key dispenser, and now has double keys, which is hilarious and we have unlimited purple weapons for a while). It was just quite noticeable after Borderlands 2, which I found pretty flawless in terms of gameplay.

Anyway, I like this game a lot. I certainly wouldn't call it disappointing, although there ARE some flaws, which doubtless other reviewers will describe to you in excessive length. But I'm having fun, with just enough familiar, and plenty of new, and actually quite a lot of back story to Borderlands 2, which is nice.

9/10 if you get it on sale

reviewText:
Played about a good 50+ hours so far, finished the main game and the Claptastic Voyage, currently busy with TVHM.

Honestly, i really don't get much of the negativity surrounding TPS, it's a fantastic game. The game has a number of flaws (in comparison to B2) but also has a lot of features that redeem it. I'll just list up the pros and cons.

Pros:

- Excellent storyline. Whereas i couldn't be arsed about B2's storyline, TPS does so a lot better. Everybody has a knack for Jack (pun intended) and TPS is focused around his side of the story that lead up to the events of B2. Don't wanna spoil it so i'll keep it short. The story will give you a lot more perspective on Jack, and why he's such a psycho hell-bent on reducing Pandora to rubble, and what morality he bears to it. You'll get to see his reasons for it.

- Plenty of new additions. For example, slag has been removed and replaced with cryo damage. It's essentialy still the same thing, as it boosts damage, but enemies will be slowed or paralyzed for a few seconds, making it a far more effective elemental weapon. A new weapon is also introduced: Lasers, which is pretty much as awesome as it sounds.

- Money is essentialy worthless in B2, with the exception of grinding slot machines. (which rarely give anything good anyway, so its mostly exchanging it for Eridium) Not the case anymore, vendors reguraly have excellent items on stock, even the occassional legendary item. And they dont come cheap. Money is an essential part, and paying a respawn fee is now something you want to avoid. Along with that, there's the 'Grinder', a machine that can turn items and weapons you don't need into something new, with a good chance of them increasing in rarity level. (for example, 3 green items can be turned into a blue one)

- Level scaling is a lot better, with the 'Triton Flats' (an area which you will reguraly be returning to) set to your current lvl as the story progresses. Backtracking, grinding and looting is thus also a lot more viable if you wish to do so.

- I've encountered a lot of bugs in B2, including a pretty gamebreaking one. It's annoying. TPS has a lot less 'rough edges', in the 50+ hours i've spent i have passed by barely any bugs at all.

- A whole new cast of characters with entirely different playstyles. Whereas B2 regurgitated some of the characters from B1 into B2 (Commando being Roland, Gunzerker being Brick, etc.) every character in the game has its very own special skillsets and are extremely enjoyable as well.

-There's lots of new enemies everywhere, which is awesome. Unfortunately though, some of them are mostly 'repackaged' enemies from B2. (Kragoons being Skags, Scavs being bandits, etc.)

Cons:

- It's shorter than B2. Fewer sidequests and a slightly shorter (though more enjoyable) storyline.

- Little new weaponry. There's the lasers they added, which are awesome, but they've mostly ported the arsenal from B2 to TPS. I would've enjoyed seeing some new weapons around. Though, thankfully, there are a good number of new legendaries (quite a lot, actually) to find, and i've encountered a few high-lvl weapons (blues/purples, though i could be wrong and these have been ported from B2 as well) that i haven't seen before. It's still a shame though. For a game that focuses so much on loot and progression, some new flavors would've definetly been appreciated. Claptastic Voyage includes a new rarity level (Glitch) and new weapons which are awesome, but you won't find them in the vanilla game so i don't really think they count.

- They've really tried to bring back that feel of humor from it's predecessors and implemented it into TPS. Yeah, i've laughed heartily a few times, but they've tried to give you the occasional chuckle every now and then. Or at least, that's the aim. Thankfully, none of it feels forced, but it's just not funny most of the time.

- The whole low gravity thing is awesome, but the fact that you have to maintain your oxygen is just annoying. Occasionaly you'll have to run off to a location containing oxygen when you're on your way. Instead of keeping the pace, you're just gonna have to stop every now and then. For absolutely no reason whatsoever. It's not a feature Gearbox, it's just annoying.

- It may not be something for everyone, but the DLC is - aside from the Claptastic Voyage (which is amazing by the way) - pretty little. B2 has huge amounts of excellent DLC (DLC done right), TPS has far less. Of course, this shouldn't affect the rating of the game, it's an add-on after all.

In conclusion, i recommend B:TPS. Though i urge every person new to the series to start out with B2 (you dont need B1 if you dont wanna), if you want some more of it, totally get TPS. It might not be brimmed with content like B2 was, nor is it a huge step up what B2 did for B1, it's still a great addition to the Borderlands franchise.

The pre-sequel is noticeable but not necessarily an improvement upon Borderlands 2. I personally like the Character Classes better and I love the new double jump/ground slam combat mechanics. The game keeps most of the good features and builds upon them.

Most missions will have you running across several maps, slogging through hordes of guys you have already killed several times, to obtain the item and then you have to go all the way back.

Outcome
-Gameplay is fun Classes are better
-Transportation/travel time sucks and there are lots of death pits
-Money is scarce and Rare’s from vending machines are overpriced and not as good as they should be
-Lots of repetitive filler in missions that takes away from the otherwise enjoyable gameplay

Love the game but sometimes it tries my patience!

reviewText:
TL;DR - worse Borderlands 2 that gets terribly frustrating and exhausting by the end missions. 4/10.

And now the long one. Let's just start with stating that this is still a Borderlands game, so if you enjoyed the previous ones you will most likely enjoy this one too, especially when playing with friends. For the most of it. Then you'll get frustrated and will want to just quit this god damn game.

Lets start with the missions. There are some nice ones, some quite unique and fun ones. But that's like 5 out of 40. The rest are all repetitive fetch quests that get unnaturally prolonged, because if not the game wouldn't be the half of what it is now. The worst part is that this applies not only to side missions, which are obviously always lower priority for production, but for main quests as well. Without spoiling, there was a mission that could be literally summarised to:

-Go to A
-A doesn't work,  you need to go to B then
-B doesn't work, ok C will for sure
-Well, C ALMOST works, you only need D to make it work
-Ok you have D? Now go back to C
-Ok C works now? ok go to B and then you'll proceed to the final part of the mission

Where story wise, it could very well and at B and be much more fun. Even worse, by the very end the WHOLE GAME feels like it is being unneccessarily prolonged, without an actual, reasonable explenation why. That leads us to writing.

The humor is worse. It's got to a level of stupidity that is actually cringe worthy and embarasing. The one part that they did well - Jack's change - is kind of destroyed by the fact that I can't state my point about it. Obviously, it's always like that in games like this, you have no dialogue choices etc, but the problem is, in other games your character doesn't make a change on it's own as well.

SPOILER STARTS HERE: I've started the game as a more or less good guy. I wanted to save the moon with Jack's help or as his help. Regardless, even though I might not be 100% rightous, I was still good. And that's the character I liked and I wanted to play as. Later, when Jack kills 4 scientist because he suspected that one of them was a traitor my character suddenly screams AWESOME. What the ♥♥♥♥? I mean, it was awesome in terms of building Jack's character, showing how voilence is changing him, but I never wanted my character to change with him, nor was I ever teased that it might happen. SPOILER OVER.

Next topic. Loot and character progression are both done terribly. Let's just say I've finished the game with weapons not higher than level 22, as a 26 level character, fighting level 28 boss. That's not how you balance loot. I've switched my sniper rifle 3 times during over 20h of gameplay. Also I have not seen a SINGLE legendary weapon, not to mention one I would actually like and want to use. Something that also didn't help with my gear progression is that I lost a TON of items by them dropping into abyss. You'd imagine they could write a piece of code that ensures loot lands on reachable place in a game that's heavily loot dependend.

Character progression can be summed up as: start with active ability, put 25 boring stat boosters after and then put an actually cool ability at level 26. Boring as hell. One thing that also needs to be mentioned here - main story balancing, combined with unrewarding loot system, pretty much makes side quests obligatory.

My last big issue with the game is it's optimization - on a GTX 780 i had very frequent drops to 30-40 even without maxing all of the settings and with turning off the PhysX. Another wierd thing with it is that even when it was running at stable 60 according to Steam FPS counter, there was TERRBILE screen tearing. G-Sync helped there, but not everyone can afford it. Then, when I switched to GTX 980Ti in the middle, it was still not achieving stable 60. What the hell. Witcher 3 runs at stable 60 in 2K, while also looking much, much better.

The other issues are not as big, but perhaps worth mentioning. Gearbox introduced a couple of new gameplay mechanics, for example oxygen in vaccum, lower gravity with booster jump and laser guns. Not a single one of those is actually fun. Oxygen is annoying, because for most of the game you don't care about it, only sometimes you are searching for O2 source nearby in panick. Lower gravity (which means higher jumps) would be fun if not the fact that level design doesn't seem to adjust to that correctly and multiple collisions are just a tiny bit too high to jump on them, even with perfectly timed booster. Laser guns are mostly useless (I found one that I was using for a bit, because it actually shot where I poitned it to, rest shoots wherever it wants).

There was also a lot of small bugs, like lacks of collisions or incorrectly placed ones, NPCs falling torso deep into terrain (mostly lunatics after their jump attack), problems with AI - NPCs walking past me peacefully while I'm in combat with their friends or launching a jump attack at a helicopter that's over lava in one of the missions, resulting in killing themselves, graphical glitches like some wierd, glowing mesh being left hanging in the air after killing one of the opponents.

To be honest it's hard to say anything good about the game aside from the fact that shooting is fun. But then the last two missions start, you have ♥♥♥♥ gear because of unrewarding loot system and you just want this to end, but it doesn't. It goes on and on and on for no logical reason other that boosting the number of hours neccessary to finish the game. I do not recommend this one.

reviewText:
This is essentially a shorter, space-themed version of Borderlands 2. Taking place and tying-in the gap between BL:1 and BL:2. A lot of people and things you'll recognize if you played the first two games. It plays nearly identically to BL:2. Not exactly the same though, now you can: Grind sh*tty weapons into (hopefully) better ones, ride around in the 'Stingray' (fun little new vehicle), Butt-slam people as you hop around in Zero-G (pretty fun) and shoot laser weapons (also pretty fun). Just about everyone is Australian too... Yaaaay?....

Not any revolutionary changes in the least... but it's not just BL:2 with a moon-themed skin slapped on like a lot of people imply. It DOES, however, feel like an extended DLC... but I have seen a handful of games with less content go for full Triple-A price, so I think it still has enough gameplay to justify the cost (I'd still say wait for a sale though, considering the majority of it does kind of just feel like BL:2 again).

All in all, If you enjoy the Borderlands universe I'd say this is worth looking into. It's a lot shorter than the first two games, so I'd wait for a sale if you do buy it. Unless you're a huge Borderlands fan and are feeling overburdened with money ;)

reviewText:
I wanted to love this game. I really wanted to love it. After the huge improvements Borderlands 2 made on Borderlands 1, you would expect another huge development with The Pre Sequal! Alas, no such improvements. In fact, it's even worse. The Pre Sequel brings memories of the original Borderlands, and not in a good way. Almost all the legendaries are from Borderlands 2, with a few new ones, and a few that have been renamed (but are still from BL2). The story.. my goodness. The story is like freshly laid crap. It has the potential to be good, but, it takes the Far Cry 3 route.... and kills the main villian when there's still a lot left to the story
The pitiful excuse for a raid boss is absolutely horrendous. It's not fun at all, unlike Terramorphus or Crawmerax. Not only that, but the DLC that they've released is even worse, bringing shame to the franchise. How can you go from great DLC such as the Secret Armory of General Knoxx and Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage to junk like the Holodome Onslaught DLC?
Unacceptable. If possible, I would wish that we don't even count this as a part of the Borderlands franchise. The ending is obviously tacked on, bringing no sense what so ever. A waste of $59.99. Mediocre in every way. The only good part of this mess is Jack, but not even he can bring this up.
I'm a die hard Borderlands fan. I have over 300 hours on the PS3 version for BL1 and 362 hours for BL2 on PC. I loved every part of BL1 and BL2. I could barely finish this game. It is one of the most disappointing games of 2014, and I do not recommend it.

Interesting Dialogue - As always, Borderlands makes the dialogue either have some deeper meaning or is flat out hilarious.
Introduction to new items - The added types of weapons, the O2 kits, and new abilites are amazing
New characters - Yo, Claptrap? For real??? lol, love the new characters

Cons:
Storyline is somewhat bland - Parts of the story are repetitive, but it does come with a rather big surprise at the end
Doesn't seem like a new" game - Although I was stoked it was so similar to Borderlands 2

reviewText:
I wanted to love this game. I really wanted to love it. After the huge improvements Borderlands 2 made on Borderlands 1, you would expect another huge development with The Pre Sequal! Alas, no such improvements. In fact, it's even worse. The Pre Sequel brings memories of the original Borderlands, and not in a good way. Almost all the legendaries are from Borderlands 2, with a few new ones, and a few that have been renamed (but are still from BL2). The story.. my goodness. The story is like freshly laid crap. It has the potential to be good, but, it takes the Far Cry 3 route.... and kills the main villian when there's still a lot left to the story
The pitiful excuse for a raid boss is absolutely horrendous. It's not fun at all, unlike Terramorphus or Crawmerax. Not only that, but the DLC that they've released is even worse, bringing shame to the franchise. How can you go from great DLC such as the Secret Armory of General Knoxx and Mr. Torgue's Campaign of Carnage to junk like the Holodome Onslaught DLC?
Unacceptable. If possible, I would wish that we don't even count this as a part of the Borderlands franchise. The ending is obviously tacked on, bringing no sense what so ever. A waste of $59.99. Mediocre in every way. The only good part of this mess is Jack, but not even he can bring this up.
I'm a die hard Borderlands fan. I have over 300 hours on the PS3 version for BL1 and 362 hours for BL2 on PC. I loved every part of BL1 and BL2. I could barely finish this game. It is one of the most disappointing games of 2014, and I do not recommend it.

reviewText: If you get this game for free or for some kind of significant discount, it may be worthwhile. Sadly, Borderlands has never been anything more than a mediocre gameplay experience with decent, varying greatly with personal taste, humor. Hilarious and entertaining for some, a complete and utter waste of time for others. Everthing unique about this game (mainly the randomly generated guns) has had no update significant enough to make it stand out from its predecessors. The new mechanics not present in previous installments are more of an annoyance than an improvement. On a final note, if you found Claptrap annoying in previous games, do not even bother playing this because there are Claptraps in every area of the game and Claptrap is a playable character. Repetative, irritating dialog from Claptrap will be enough to make someone who enjoyed the previous games but hated Claptrap want to stay away from this entirely.
